seg.seg: ... the excellent Law. The ymatu assembly of the community of monks we revere (with) the head [and] (front of the head).
... jātakas ... he entered dear lives previously. 1. Beloved ones, sons, harem[s] and possessions he has abandoned without (greed).
Liebe Söhne, Harem [und] Besitztümer hat er [scil. der Buddha] ohne (Geiz) aufgegeben.
Dear sons, harem [and] possessions he [i.e. the Buddha] has given up without (miserliness).
... not begging ... he has honoured the Laws previously, the honourable one. All that (you have done?) for our sake ...
... hat zuerst die Gesetze verehrt der Würdige.
... [he] has first venerated the laws, the dignified one.
in the saṃsāra. 2. These sufferings he put onto his mind, [but] his own suffering has been indifferent to him. In three asaṃkhyeyas [and] hundred kalpas the teacher has assembled
(the Law) ... (Thus) the Buddha thought (by himself), «to whom shall I first make reverence?», [but] he found no one worthy of reverence he could have made reverence to. 3. The Law ...
(Thus) the Buddha thought (by himself), «to whom shall I first make reverence?», [but] he found no one worthy of reverence he could have made reverence to.
(So) hat der Buddha in (seinem) Herzen gedacht: "Wen soll ich zuerst verehren?" [Aber] er fand keinen Verehrungswürdigen, den er hätte verehren können.
Thus the Buddha thought in (his) heart: "Who shall I venerate first?" [But] he did not find any venerable one, whom he could have venerated.
Wem könnte ich [wohl] Verehrung erweisen?
Who could I pay homage to?
... You, o Buddha, remind the sons of the five births of the end. Like a father (who leaves) [his] possessions (to his sons) when dying,
Die Söhne der fünf Geburtsklassen erinnerst du, o Buddha, an das Ende [d.h. an den Tod].
The sons of the five incarnations, oh Buddha, you remind of the end [i.e. of death].
(thus the teacher) has left the possessions of (the Law) [4.] to us. Here they (= the possessions of the Law) will turn round [and] go among men [and] gods; countless pleasures ...;

Here they (= the possessions of the law) will turn round and go among men and gods; countless pleasures …; he who writes down the law, shows his gratitude to the Buddha; as many akṣaras as there are in a book, so many monasteries will the first make.
he who writes down the Law shows his gratitude to the Buddha; as many akṣaras as there are in a book, so many monasteries will the first make. 5.
Wieviel Akṣaras in einem Buche [sind], so [viele] Klöster wird der eine bauen.
As many akṣaras [as there are] in a book, so [many] monasteries the one will build.
(Wer) das Gesetz [auf]schreibt, der tut [nach] dem Willen des Buddha.
(Who[ever] writes [down] the Law acts [according to] the Buddha's will.
... will be great merit. Through asaṃkhyeyas in the births the teacher has assembled the Law. [Even] if he writes one single stanza as holy text
Durch Asaṃkhyeyas [hindurch] hat der Meister in [seinen] Geburten das Gesetz gesammelt.
Through [long] asaṃkhyeyas, the master in [his] incarnations has assembled the law.
... merits will have the teacher. Thus [it] has been said by the teachers. Two the Buddha has called leaders in the front army
... possessions ... from the leader he [is] the leader. These citizens of the villages [and] of the boroughs delivered the possession without greed. The wish ...
7. May we not be born among heretics, may we not practice [any] magical saying [as] the right doctrine! ... of the Law ...
Unter Irrlehrern möchten wir nicht [wieder]geboren werden, nicht möchten wir einen [beliebigen] Spruch(?) für die rechte Lehre(?) halten.
Among teachers of false doctrines may we not be [re]born, may we not [mis]take a random saying(?) for the right teaching(?).

The fragment is currently missing. On the photo in the plates volume (II, 17; photos 8a and 8b), a small fragment is not included. This fragment must have contained a1 ssaṅkṣiṃ wi and b6 ṣimäs ca.

yä(rk)s(ā)t: This restoration of 153 makes sense in the context, but this stem of the verb yärk- is not attested otherwise (cf. e.g. 467). The reading is in fact not very likely to be correct: the last consonantal element of the second akṣara is certainly s, but it cannot have been only k, since it is too low and too far to the right. It is more likely to be the third consonantal element of a heavier ligature.
153 restores puk täm was ṣru(maṣ yāmtsāt klopant kropa)t saṃsāraṃ "Alles das hat er unseretwegen getan. Leiden hat er gesammelt im Saṃsāra.". If correct, ṣru(maṣ) would violate the metre.
– – klo(pant): 153 restores (ālu) klo(pant), which does not seem possible. Parts of the large akṣara lu should still have been visible.

/// ñc ptāñkät: 153 restores (tämne ṣñi āri)ñc ptāñkät pälskāt "(So) hat der Buddha in (seinem) Herzen gedacht". If correct, (ṣñi āri)ñc would violate the metre. The metre would be all right if the original text had e.g. (tämne ṣñ= āri)ñc pättāñkät.
märkampa(l): Possibly märkampa(lṣās niṣpalntu), cf. b1.
päñ-cmolwāṣnis: For päñ-cmolwāṣinäs. See a comparable inversion of the vowels of the last two syllables in b4 mṣapantnis and b5 mṣapantniṣ.
lipäṣ: The restoration of this word and the rest of the lacuna follows 153. The present stem of läyp-s-tr. is so far unattested (cf. 851; 810).
sas: Literally 'one', but here probably 'the first', cf. b4-6 sas 'one', wät 'second', trit 'third'.
mṣapantnis: For mṣapantinäs. See a comparable inversion of the vowels of the last two syllables in a6 päñ-cmolwāṣnis and b5 mṣapantniṣ.
ānt ratkaṃ: Apparently a compound 'front army'.

The beginning of the line is restored as pekäntāśśi 'of the writers' by 153. Indeed, it is likely that the expression mṣapantnis ānt ratkaṃ is part of a metaphor, but Thomas' restoration violates the metre.
mṣapantniṣ: For mṣapantinäṣ. See a comparable inversion of the vowels of the last two syllables in a6 päñ-cmolwāṣnis and b4 mṣapantnis.
ṣukṣeñi āpṣātrikāñ: The metre rather requires 4 + 3 syllables here.
: For the reading and the restoration, cf. p. 316. Nevertheless, the metre is not regular: the first segment of mar wi(c) wrāṣimäs cam sīddhāṃ is 5 instead of the required 4 syllables.

märkampal(ṣ)ā(s) – – ntwaṃ: A restoration märkampal(ṣ)ā(s niṣpal)ntwaṃ, a frequent expression in this text, is excluded because the top of the akṣara ntwaṃ is preserved. Also a (metrically incorrect) spelling of the same as märkampal(ṣ)ā(s niṣpalä)ntwaṃ is impossible, because it would have taken more space. Theoretically, (cmolä)ntwaṃ would be possible.

Text notes

a3. yä(rk)s(ā)t: This restoration of [[Thomas 1957]]: 153 makes sense in the context, but this stem of the verb yärk- is not attested otherwise (cf. e.g. [[Peyrot, ToSu]]: 467). The reading is in fact not very likely to be correct: the last consonantal element of the second akṣara is certainly s, but it cannot have been only k, since it is too low and too far to the right. It is more likely to be the third consonantal element of a heavier ligature.

a4. [[Thomas 1957]]: 153 restores puk täm was ṣru(maṣ yāmtsāt klopant kropa)t saṃsāraṃ "Alles das hat er unseretwegen getan. Leiden hat er gesammelt im Saṃsāra.". If correct, ṣru(maṣ) would violate the metre.

a4. – – klo(pant): [[Thomas 1957]]: 153 restores (ālu) klo(pant), which does not seem possible. Parts of the large akṣara lu should still have been visible.

a4. try esaṃkhesaṃ: For try asaṃkhesaṃ.

a5. /// ñc ptāñkät: [[Thomas 1957]]: 153 restores (tämne ṣñi āri)ñc ptāñkät pälskāt "(So) hat der Buddha in (seinem) Herzen gedacht". If correct, (ṣñi āri)ñc would violate the metre. The metre would be all right if the original text had e.g. (tämne ṣñ= āri)ñc pättāñkät.

a5-a6. märkampa(l): Possibly märkampa(lṣās niṣpalntu), cf. b1.

a6. päñ-cmolwāṣnis: For päñ-cmolwāṣinäs. See a comparable inversion of the vowels of the last two syllables in b4 mṣapantnis and b5 mṣapantniṣ.

b1. lipäṣ: The restoration of this word and the rest of the lacuna follows [[Thomas 1957]]: 153. The present stem of läyp-s-tr. is so far unattested (cf. [[Malzahn 2010]]: 851; [[Peyrot, ToSu]]: 810).

b2. sas: Literally 'one', but here probably 'the first', cf. [[A 11]] b4-6 sas 'one', wät 'second', trit 'third'.

b4. mṣapantnis: For mṣapantinäs. See a comparable inversion of the vowels of the last two syllables in a6 päñ-cmolwāṣnis and b5 mṣapantniṣ.

b4. ānt ratkaṃ: Apparently a compound 'front army'.

b5. The beginning of the line is restored as pekäntāśśi 'of the writers' by [[Thomas 1957]]: 153. Indeed, it is likely that the expression mṣapantnis ānt ratkaṃ is part of a metaphor, but Thomas' restoration violates the metre.

b5. mṣapantniṣ: For mṣapantinäṣ. See a comparable inversion of the vowels of the last two syllables in a6 päñ-cmolwāṣnis and b4 mṣapantnis.

b5. ṣukṣeñi āpṣātrikāñ: The metre rather requires 4 + 3 syllables here.

b6.: For the reading and the restoration, cf. [[TG]]: p. 316. Nevertheless, the metre is not regular: the first segment of mar wi(c) wrāṣimäs cam sīddhāṃ is 5 instead of the required 4 syllables.

b6. märkampal(ṣ)ā(s) – – ntwaṃ: A restoration märkampal(ṣ)ā(s niṣpal)ntwaṃ, a frequent expression in this text, is excluded because the top of the akṣara ntwaṃ is preserved. Also a (metrically incorrect) spelling of the same as märkampal(ṣ)ā(s niṣpalä)ntwaṃ is impossible, because it would have taken more space. Theoretically, (cmolä)ntwaṃ would be possible.
